LOAN AND PROJECT SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Socialist Republic of Viet Nam  
   
Classification  Targeting classification: General intervention 
Sector: Energy 
Subsector: Hydropower generation  
Themes: Sustainable economic growth, inclusive social 
development, environmental sustainability 
Subthemes: Fostering physical infrastructure development, 
indigenous peoples, involuntary settlement  
   
Environment  Category  A.  An  environmental  impact  assessment  (EIA)  was 
Assessment  undertaken and its summary (SEIA) was circulated on 21 August 
2006.  
   
Project Description  The Project consists of the construction of a 156 megawatt (MW) 
hydropower  plant  in  the  Vu  Gia-Thu  Bon  river  basin  in 
Quang Nam province, central Viet Nam. A 110 meter (m) high 
roller compacted concrete (RCC) dam with a crest length of 367 m 
will be built across the Song Bung river. The dam will form a 
reservoir with a surface area of 15.8 square kilometers (km2) at a 
full  supply  level  of  222.5  m  above  sea  level.  Water  from  the 
reservoir will be conveyed through a 3.1 kilometer (km) tunnel to 
the power station, and released along a short tailrace canal to the 
Song Bung river about 5 km downstream of the dam.  
  
The Project is located in Nam Giang district (bordering the Lao 
People’s Democratic Republic) of Quang Nam province in central 
Viet Nam predominantly inhabited by indigenous people belonging 
to  the  Co  Tu  ethnic  minority.  The  Project  will  result  in  the 
relocation of 206 mainly Co Tu households in Zuoih commune of 
Nam Giang district. The Project is also located near to the Song 
Thanh Nature Reserve, about 140 hectares (ha) of which will be 
inundated. 
 
Comprehensive assessments of the Project’s environmental and 
social impacts have been undertaken and appropriate mitigation 
measures  have  been  included  in  the  Project’s  design.  These 
include  restoration  and  improvement  of  lost  livelihoods  in  a 
culturally  appropriate  manner  for  project-affected  persons, 
provision  of  social  infrastructure,  and  conservation  offset  to 
compensate  for  adverse  impacts  on  the  Song  Thanh  Nature 
Reserve.

ii   
Rationale  Viet Nam has maintained a GDP growth rate of over 7.5% per 
year during the last 10 years and has reduced the incidence of 
poverty from 58% in 1993 to less than 20% in 2007. This has 
been achieved through rapid industrialization and urbanization, 
which have increased demand for electricity. Electricity demand 
has grown at an average rate of 15% per annum; it is forecast to 
maintain the same rate until 2010 and then to fall to 11% by 2015. 
 
The planned capacity addition for 2007–2017 is over 40,000 MW, 
of which over 13,000 MW is already under construction. The total 
investment  requirement  in  the  power  sector  for  2007–2012  is 
about $24 billion. Of this amount, Viet Nam Electricity (EVN) plans 
to  make  an  investment  of  $16  billion;  non-EVN  investments, 
including from the private sector, are expected to be $8 billion. 
Financing from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) would bridge 
the financing gap in the sector and complement financing from 
other sources. 
 
The Project is the first hydropower project in Viet Nam to receive 
financing  from  a  multilateral  financial  institution.  It  has  been 
designed  to  address  environmental  and  social  impacts  in  a 
sustainable and socially inclusive manner. The Project will also 
promote integrated water resources management (IWRM) in the 
river  basin  through  policy  dialogue  and  associated  technical 
assistance (TA). 
 
Impact and Outcome  The  Project’s  impact  will  be  a  contribution  to  Viet  Nam’s 
increasing power demand in an environmentally sustainable and 
socially inclusive manner.   
 
The  Project’s  outcome  will  be  increased  power  generation 
capacity  in  Quang  Nam  Province,  Central  Viet  Nam  and, 
mitigation of adverse environmental impacts, and restoration and 
improvement of the livelihoods of project-affected persons.  
   
Project Investment Plan   The  total  investment  cost  of  the  Project  is  estimated  at 
$267.3 million.  
   
Financing Plan  The Project is proposed to be financed using a combination of a 
$196.0 million loan from ADB’s ordinary capital resources (OCR), 
a loan equivalent to $22.3 million from Viet Nam Development 
Bank, and a $49.0 million contribution from EVN financed through 
internal cash generation.

iii
  The  ADB  loan  of  $196  million  will  be  provided  under  ADB’s 
London inter bank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending facility. The 
loan will have a 25-year term including a grace period of 5 years, 
an  interest rate  determined  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  LIBOR-
based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per annum,  
and such other terms and conditions set forth in the draft loan and 
project agreements.  
 
Allocation and Relending  The Socialist Republic of Viet Nam will act as the borrower for the 
Terms  ADB loan, which will be relent to EVN.  The Ministry of Finance 
will levy a relending fee of 1.5 % on semiannual loan repayments 
(loan amortization plus interest).  
   
Period of Utilization  Until 30 June 2014 
   
Estimated Project  31 December 2013 
Completion Date 
   
Implementation  The Project will be implemented by the Song Bung 4 Hydropower 
Arrangements  management board, a project management board of EVN. The 
management  board  will  be  responsible  for  the  day-to-day 
management of implementation of the Project under the overall 
supervision  of  EVN.  The  technical  design  and  procurement  of 
major civil works contracts and equipment are subject to approval 
by EVN. The resettlement component will be carried out through a 
committee  consisting  of  representatives  from  the  management 
board and the Nam Giang district people’s committee reporting to 
Quang Nam province people’s committee.   
   
Executing Agency  Viet Nam Electricity (EVN) 
   
Procurement  Civil works contracts and equipment to be financed under the loan 
will  be  procured  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Procurement 
Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time).    
   
Consulting Services  The  loan  will  finance  the  following  consulting  services:  (i)  an 
international  firm  of  consultants  for  project  supervision  on 
technical, contractual, resettlement, and environmental aspects; 
and (ii) a national nongovernment organization or consultant firm 
for independent monitoring of social and environment safeguards. 
 
  The  international  and  national  consultants  will  be  recruited  in 
accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants 
(2007,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  Government 
requested  advance  action  for  recruitment  of  consultants  to 
minimize  delays  in  project  implementation.  ADB  has  approved 
advance recruitment and informed the Government that this would 
not commit ADB to financing the consultants.

iv   
Project Benefits and  The  Project  will  help  to  meet  the  rapidly  growing  demand  for 
Beneficiaries  electricity  in  Viet  Nam.  The  availability  of  reliable  and  cheap 
electricity  is  an  essential  prerequisite  if  Viet  Nam’s  rapid  and 
socially  inclusive  economic  growth  is  to  be  maintained  and 
poverty reduced. The Project will also improve the stability and 
overall  reliability  of  the  power  system,  and  further  reduce  the 
dependency of Viet Nam’s power sector on fossil fuels, with their 
associated greenhouse gas emissions.  The project will result in 
carbon  emission  reductions  because  it  will  replace  fossil-fuel- 
based power generation.  
 
The  Project  will  improve  accessibility  to  and  common 
infrastructure facilities of hitherto remote areas in Quang Nam 
province. The livelihood improvement component of the Project 
will  improve  the  well-being  of  project-affected  persons  who 
currently depend on subsistence livelihoods.  
 
Risks and Assumptions  The main technical risks of the Project relate to the design and 
construction of the 110 m high concrete dam and the geotechnical 
risks of the dam site, power plant site, and alignment of the tunnel. 
The geotechnical condition of the project site is good and is not 
expected  to  cause  major  problems  during  construction  or 
operation. Adequate contingency provisions have been included 
in the cost estimates to deal with possible cost overruns caused 
by technical risks. The amount of electricity to be generated by the 
Project  depends  on  the  hydrology  of  the  river;  this  has  been 
thoroughly assessed and the implications of reduced inflows on 
electricity  output  have  been  incorporated  into  the  sensitivity 
analysis. 
 
The Project also depends on the overall financial viability of the 
power sector. Viet Nam’s power sector is currently undergoing 
rapid expansion to meet the high forecast demand growth rate 
and any drop in the growth rate caused by an economic slowdown 
is likely to result in surplus capacity in 2010–2015. The increasing 
debt service commitment and likely increase in fossil fuel prices 
(Viet Nam  is  a  net  exporter  of  fossil  fuel)  may  also  require 
sustained tariff increases to maintain the viability of the sector. 
 
The social risks of the Project relate to the implementation risk of 
the resettlement and ethnic minority development plan, especially 
the livelihood improvement plan for affected people. A grant of 
$2 million,  financed  through  the  Japan  Fund  for  Poverty 
Reduction,  will  be  provided  to  finance  livelihood  improvement 
activities that are beyond current government practice.

v
  The environmental issues relate to the adverse impact on aquatic 
  species  caused  by  changes  to  flow  regime  in  the  river  and 
increased access to Song Thanh Nature Reserve because of the 
Project.  The  environmental  management  plan  (EMP)  has 
recommended appropriate measures to minimize these impacts. 
However, proper implementation of the EMP during the operations 
phase of the Project remains a risk that needs to be addressed 
through the monitoring mechanisms of the Government and ADB.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for the Song Bung 4 Hydropower Project. The country strategy 
and  program  update  for  2006–20081 included  the  Project.  ADB  has  approved  two  technical 
assistance (TA) grants to prepare the Project .2 
 
II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
1.  Macroeconomic  Performance  and  Linkages  with  Country  Strategy  and 
Program 
2.  Viet Nam’s socioeconomic development since 1993 has been remarkable. The country’s 
success in reducing poverty level from 58% in 1993 to less than 20% in 2007 is unprecedented. 
During this period, gross domestic product (GDP) per capita has increased from $288 to $850 and 
economic growth has averaged 7.5% per year with the growth rate for 2007 reaching 8.5%. The 
structure of the economy has been transformed since 1993—the share of the energy-intensive 
industry and service sectors has increased at the expense of the agriculture sector. The high 
economic growth has been underpinned by robust and sustainable levels of investment equal to 
40%  of  GDP  in  2007.  An  increasing  share  of  investment,  especially  in  the  manufacturing 
industries and service sector, has been made by the private sector. Foreign direct investment 
approvals exceeded $20 billion in 2007, an increase of over 80% compared with 2006. 
 
3.  The  Government’s  strategy  for  maintaining  its  impressive  record  of  sustainable  and 
socially inclusive economic growth is outlined in the Socio-Economic Development Plan (SEDP) 
for 2006–2010 approved by the National Assembly in May 2006. The SEDP acknowledges the 
critical importance of private sector participation, good governance, and integration with the global 
economy  through,  among  others,  Viet  Nam’s  membership  of  the  World  Trade  Organization. 
ADB’s country strategy and program for Viet Nam 2007–20103 supports the key objectives of the 
SEDP  in  achieving  a  balance  between  business-led  economic  growth,  social  equity,  and 
environmental sustainability while strengthening the governance of public sector institutions and 
supporting private sector investments in the productive sectors of the economy. The country 
strategy and program identifies the critical importance of removing infrastructure bottlenecks in 
the energy and transport sectors to further increase the competitiveness of Viet Nam’s private-
sector-led manufacturing and service sectors.  
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Major Challenges Facing the Power and Energy Sectors 
a.  Meeting Rapidly Increasing Demand   
4.  The key challenge facing the power sector is maintaining adequate investments to meet 
the rapid growth in demand. The performance of Viet Nam’s power sector and the government’s 
power sector strategy  is described in Appendix 2. The  projected power generation capacity 
addition during 2007–2017 (Table 1) is over 40,000 megawatts (MW), of which over 13,000 MW 
are under construction and will be commissioned by 2012. Managing an expansion program that 
is expected to increase the system capacity by more than four times within 10 years will be a 
major challenge for the institutions in the power sector. EVN will undertake more than half of the

5.  The Government is keen to reduce Viet Nam’s energy intensity (0.66 tons of oil equivalent 
[toe] per $1,000 GDP) to a level similar to those of its neighbors (0.40 toe per $1,000 GDP in 
Malaysia and 0.38 toe per $1,000 GDP in Thailand). The Government has formulated a national 
energy efficiency and conservation program, consisting of economic incentives, capacity building 
and administrative measures, and time-bound efficiency targets.  Although the program covers all 
sectors of the economy it focuses on the rapidly expanding industrial sector. The objectives of the 
Program  are  (i)  to  establish  energy  efficiency  programs  at  60%  of  large  and  medium-sized 
energy-consuming consumers; (ii) to formulate an energy-efficiency building code; (iii) to achieve 
a 3–5 % reduction in national energy consumption and a 5% reduction in industrial energy 
consumption by 2010; and (iv) to achieve a 5–8 % reduction in national energy consumption and 
an 8% reduction in industrial energy consumption by 2015 per unit of economic output.

7.  The total investment requirement in the power sector for 2007–2012 will be about $24 
billion, of which EVN will invest $16 billion and others will invest about $8 billion. A similar level of 
investment  is  expected  to  be  maintained  for  the  period  2013–2017.  The  net  internal  cash

generation of EVN for the period 2007–2012 is expected to be about $9 billion, and its net 
borrowings to be about $7 billion. EVN is increasingly resorting to borrowing on commercial terms 
from export credit agencies and from ADB on ordinary capital resources (OCR) terms. The World 
Bank is also considering lending to EVN on OCR equivalent terms. EVN also intends to raise 
funding in the international and domestic capital markets through a series of bond issues.  
 
8.  Since its creation, EVN has been profitable and has financed the rapid expansion of 
Viet Nam’s electricity sector without resorting to significant fiscal subsidies. The key financial 
performance indicators; debt service cover ratio, self-financing ratio, and receivables have been 
maintained within prudential limits while the average end user tariff had been maintained at 
$0.051 per kilowatt-hour (kWh) until 2007. The average tariff was increased at the beginning of 
2007 to $0.053/kWh and a further tariff increase of 5% is expected in the second half of 2008. 
Sustained tariff increases are required to maintain adequate levels of debt service coverage and 
financing new investments because of increasing debt financing and financial obligations for 
power purchase from independent power producers (IPP).  
 
c.  Environmental and Social Issues  
9.  The  rapid  expansion  of  Viet  Nam’s  power  sector  will  inevitably  result  in  significant 
environmental and social impacts. The addition of over 20,000 MW of coal power generation 
capacity will contribute to increased greenhouse gas emissions. However, the current level of per 
capita greenhouse gas emissions in Viet Nam is among the lowest in the world. Supercritical and 
ultra-supercritical boiler technologies can help to increase efficiency and reduce greenhouse gas 
emissions per kWh produced. The Government is keen on applying these advanced technologies 
and has taken a decision that new coal power plants using imported coal will use supercritical 
boiler  technologies.  Hydropower  projects  involve  significant  resettlement  and  environment 
impacts. The Government has strengthened its approach to mitigation of social and environmental 
impacts  through  improved  compensation,  resettlement,  and  rehabilitation  arrangements  for 
project-affected  persons.  The  Government  also  supports  the  enactment  of  legislation  to 
mainstream the benefit sharing of hydropower projects with the affected communities based on 
the recommendations of ADB TA.4  
 
2.  ADB Sector Experience 
10.  ADB  has  approved  three  OCR  loans5 amounting  to  $1,480  million  and  three  Asian 
Development Fund (ADF) loans6 amounting to $186.3 million for Viet Nam’s power sector. The 
ADF  loans  were  primarily  for  extensions  and  rehabilitation  of  distribution  networks. 
Implementation has been satisfactory, and most of the financial and safeguard related covenants 
have been complied with. The sector reform covenants, which were mainly related to enactment 
of the Electricity Law and establishment of the regulatory agency, have also been complied with,

4.  Lessons on Hydropower Development 
14.  In  2000,  the  World  Commission  on  Dams  (WCD)  published  a  global  review  of  dam 
projects. While recognizing the important contribution of dams, the report highlighted several 
shortcomings—including  high  variability  in  delivering  predicted  outcomes,  impoverishment  of 
affected communities, and limited success in dealing with environmental impacts. Although such 
problems  are  often  attributed  to  project  planning,  ineffective  implementation  of  mitigation 
measures  during  the  operation  phase  also  contributed.  An  evaluation  of  four  hydropower 
projects13 undertaken by ADB, also concluded that many problems were associated with project 
planning; and attributed them to weak public participation, inadequate attention to environmental 
protection  measures  and  monitoring,  and  lack  of  attention  to  livelihood  restoration.  Post-
evaluation of the Nam Leuk hydropower project14 in the Lao People’s Democratic Republic (Lao 
PDR) raised a number of issues that went beyond the physical implementation timetable of the 
project, including how to replace lost fisheries and provide clean water supplies to affected 
communities.  
 
15.  Many of these lessons are reflected in ADB’s framework of social, environmental, and 
sector policies—in particular, the identification of project-specific and cumulative impacts, and the 
design of mitigation measures. During the preparation of the Project, extensive consultations were 
undertaken and alternative mitigation options were explored with local communities. Livelihood 
development measures were proposed to cover upstream and downstream communities to offset 
any loss of income due to adverse impacts on fisheries. Links were established to complementary 
donor-financed programs such as the Biodiversity Conservation Corridors Initiative15 to provide an 
integrated approach to environmental mitigation. At a policy level, longer term support to local 
communities is being explored with the Government through proposed ADB TA on a benefit 
sharing arrangement for project-affected communities (footnote 4).

Greater Mekong Subregion countries. While ADB finances hydropower projects as public sector 
investments, it will play a catalytic role in mobilizing private sector investment for thermal power

b.  Mobilizing Financial Resources to the Power Sector 
18.  ADB will also increasingly leverage co-financing from other financiers in the sector. This 
will include (i) providing political risk and partial credit guarantees, (ii) acting as lender of record 
under a complementary financing scheme, and (iii) providing guarantees to export credit agencies 
and other commercial financiers to mitigate political and other risks of a project. ADB will also 
assist public sector entities in the sector to access international capital markets by providing 
advisory and risk-sharing instruments under the innovation and efficiency initiative. 
 
c.  Improving the Regulatory Framework of the Power Sector 
19.  Starting in 1997, ADB has played a catalytic role in Viet Nam’s power sector reform 
program through several technical assistance grants. ADB has an ongoing Power Market Design

targeted TA to MOIT in close collaboration with other donors active in the sector. The World Bank 
and AFD are also actively involved in assisting the Government with power sector reform.

are general capacity building in strategic and cumulative environment assessment, livelihood 
improvement,  and  exploring  possible  revenue  sharing  mechanisms  with  project-affected 
communities. ADB will actively promote the adoption of clean and more efficient technologies for

III.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
22.  The impact of the proposed Project will be to contribute to meeting Viet Nam’s electricity 
demand with reliable and economical sources of electricity generation using the country’s natural 
resources. The Project will also set an example for environmentally sustainable and socially 
inclusive hydropower development. The outcome of the Project is increased power generation 
capacity in Quang Nam Province, Central Viet Nam and, mitigation of adverse environmental 
impacts, and restoration and improvement of the livelihoods of project-affected persons. The 
Design and Monitoring Framework of the Project is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Outputs 
1.  Construction of the Hydroelectric Plant and Related Infrastructure 
23.  The project site is in the central province of Quang Nam, about 950 km south of Hanoi. 
The Project includes the construction of a 156 MW hydropower plant on the Bung river, a tributary 
of the Vu Gia river. The Project forms a cascade with the proposed Song Bung 2 hydropower 
project  (located  upstream  of  the  Project)  and  Song  Bung  5  hydropower  project  (located 
downstream of the Project). A 110 meter (m) high roller compacted concrete (RCC) dam will 
capture the flow of water from the watershed of the Bung river, creating a reservoir of 15.8 square 
kilometers (km2) surface area in Zuoih and Ta Bhing communes of Nam Giang district in Quang 
Nam province. Water from the reservoir will be conveyed through a 3.1 kilometer (km) tunnel and 
will drop about 26 m to an aboveground power house. The water discharged from the power 
house will be returned through a short tailrace canal to the Song Bung river, 5 km downstream of 
the dam. The Project will also include a double-circuit 220-kV transmission line about 35 km long 
from the power house to Thanh My in Nam Giang district. On average, 491 gigawatt-hours (GWh) 
of power will be provided annually to the EVN grid. The main infrastructure components consist of 
the concrete dam with integral gated spillway; intake structure, headrace tunnel, surge shaft, 
pressure shaft, and pressure tunnel in the underground works; a power house consisting of two

2.  Resettlement of Affected Communities 
24.  The  reservoir  will  result  in  the  inundation  of  four  villages  and  the  relocation  of  
206 households, including the center of Zuoih commune in Nam Giang district—one of the most 
remote and mountainous communes in the district. The reservoir will flood the agricultural land of 
52 households in two other villages in Ta Binh commune. The affected persons belong to the Co 
Tu ethnic minority group and over 70% of them are below the national poverty line. For the 
relocating  villages,  the  Project  will  provide  new  resettlement  sites,  including  associated 
infrastructure (such as access roads) and better common facilities (such as schools and health 
facilities); and provide assistance to restore and improve the livelihoods in a culturally sensitive 
manner. The proposed resettlement sites are in the same commune and have been selected on 
the basis of a thorough analysis of the potential for improving the livelihoods of affected persons 
based on upland and wet rice cultivation, collection of non-timber forestry products, livestock, and 
fishponds. EVN will finance infrastructure facilities, including housing, agriculture and livestock 
inputs,  transitional  cash  allowances,  and  cash  compensation  for  lost  assets  according  to 
prevailing government regulations. A complementary grant of $2 million financed by Japan Fund 
for Poverty Reduction (JFPR) will finance enhanced livelihood improvement, including capacity 
building for project-affected persons, which goes beyond current government practices.

6.  Social Safeguard Issues 
34.  The Project is located in one of the poorest and most remote parts of central Viet Nam 
(Nam  Giang  district of  Quang  Nam  province),  predominantly  inhabited  by  the Co  Tu  ethnic 
minority who have had little contact with the mainstream Kinh people. The Co Tu people maintain 
a  traditional  lifestyle  based  on  subsistence  agriculture  and  collection  of  non-timber  forest 
products,  which  provides  most  of  their  cash  income.  The  Project  will  result  in  the  physical 
relocation of four Co Tu villages in Zuoih commune—comprising 206 households, the loss of a 
significant portion of agricultural land, and the commune center housing the school and health 
center. The Project will also affect the agricultural lands of three other communes (Ta Binh, Ca 
Dy, and Thanh My) with majority Co Tu populations because of land acquisition for construction 
sites and the transmission line associated with the Project. It is estimated that a further 1,500–
2,000 Kinh households in the neighboring Dai Loc district will have their livelihoods affected 
because of the expected reduction in fishing in the Song Bung river.

have been mainstreamed into the resettlement plan and a combined resettlement and ethnic

of extensive consultations with affected persons, and emphasizes maintaining traditional culture 
and  improving  livelihoods.  A  participatory  implementation  arrangement  for  resettlement  is

8.  Clean Development Mechanism (CDM) 
38.  As  the  Project  involves  significant  financial  commitments  to  mitigate  the  social  and

projects financed by EVN. As a result, EVN is seeking additional revenues through the CDM to 
improve the financial viability of the Project. The Project qualifies as a CDM project under the 
approved methodology of the CDM executive board as the power density of the Project (i.e., the 
ratio between installed generation capacity in MW and the surface area of the reservoir at full 
supply  level  in  sq.  km)  is  greater  than  4.  A  project  design  document  will  be  prepared  for 
submission to the CDM Executive Board. A brief CDM assessment report has been prepared and 
is attached as Supplementary Appendix I.

IV.  PROJECT BENEFITS, IMPACTS, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Project Benefits  
1.  Economic Viability 
52.  The  economic  analysis  of  the  Project  was  undertaken  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines  for  the  Economic  Analysis  of  Projects.28 The  costs  were  derived  from  the  cost 
estimates  in  Appendix  4,  excluding  transfer  payments  such  as  taxes  and  interest  during 
construction,  but  including  social  and  environment  mitigation  measures.  It  is  assumed  that 
environment and social costs are fully internalized through the inclusion of mitigation costs. The 
environmental benefits of the Project attributed to the reduction in greenhouse gas emissions 
because fossil-fuel-based power plants will be replaced have been taken into account in the 
economic analysis. Economic costs are expressed in constant 2006 prices and costs incurred in 
foreign currency are converted to a domestic price numeraire using a shadow exchange rate 
factor29 of 1.1.   
 
53.  The economic benefits of electricity produced by the Project have been determined by 
comparing the with- and without-Project scenarios. The without-Project scenario would cause 
(i) suboptimal operation of the power system, resulting in a higher operating cost per unit of 
electricity generated compared with the with-Project scenario; and (ii) load shedding because of 
inadequate generation capacity. The former is considered the non-incremental benefit of the 
Project and is valued at the resource cost saving; the latter is considered an incremental benefit 
and is valued at the willingness to pay (WTP) by consumers. Detailed economic analysis in 
Appendix 8 shows an economic internal rate of return (EIRR) of 14.78% and net present value 
(NPV) of $48.54 million at a discount rate of 12%. The sensitivity analysis shows that the Project 
is economically viable even under combined adverse conditions.

3.  Social Benefits 
56.  The Project will provide access and improvements in communication, health, education, 
and improved livelihood opportunities to an area that has remained isolated and remote from the

benefit from these opportunities through the provision of assistance to adapt to new livelihoods

B.  Project Impacts 
1.  Environmental Impacts 
57.  Change in Hydrology Downstream of the Dam. The water flow in the river stretch 
between the dam and power station will be almost negligible, and flows downstream of the power 
station will be significantly affected depending on the operation regime of the power station. If the 
power station is operated as a peaking plant as expected, there will be significant fluctuations in 
the water level, which could be as high as 1.5 m in the immediate vicinity of the power station. 
This fluctuation would diminish further downstream, (20 km from power station) reducing to 0.2 m 
in the vicinity of villages in Dai Loc district.  
 
58.  Increased Access to Song Thanh Nature Reserve. The reservoir will inundate about 
143 hectares (ha) of the Song Thanh Nature Reserve, which is less than 0.2% of the area of the 
reserve. More importantly, there will be increased access to the nature reserve through the 
reservoir and the realigned highway. The capacity building for Song Thanh Nature Reserve 
authorities and the conservation offset will contribute to preserving biodiversity in the project area, 
specifically the Song Thanh Nature Reserve.  
 
59.  Impacts on Aquatic Ecology and Fauna. The altered hydrology in the Bung river will 
cause adverse impacts on the aquatic ecology of the river as the diurnal fluctuations in the water 
level and the dry sections of the river will affect the biological productivity of the river and reduce 
the fish populations. The migratory barrier of the Song Bung 4 dam, and later the Song Bung 5

C.  Project Risks 
1.  Technical Risks of the Project 
61.  The Project will have several types of technical risks, including those related to geology 
and hydrology. The design has taken steps to avoid or minimize these risks. In general, the 
design  of  the  various  project  components  is  conventional  and  within  accepted  norms  and 
practices. The dam height is in the midrange for this type of dam (RCC dams have been built 
higher than 190 m), and turbines with the proposed range of head and discharges have been 
installed  in  many  other  projects.  The  hydrological  risk  during  construction  is  minimal  as 
overtopping of an RCC dam is quite acceptable and construction can proceed once the flood has 
passed. The spillway of the Project is designed in line with Vietnamese standards to pass the 
5,000-year flood of 15,000 cubic meters per second (m3/s) without expected damage. Stability of 
the dam has been checked for a probable maximum flood event and, although such a flood could 
overtop the dam and cause extensive damage to ancillary works, it would not endanger the 
structural integrity of the dam itself. The geotechnical risks at the dam site, tunnel and power 
house site are expected to be manageable because geological conditions in the project area are 
good.  
 
2.  Financial Risks  
62.  The  financial  risks  of  the  Project  relate  to  cost  overruns  caused  by  technical  risks, 
implementation delays, and reduction in plant output caused by adverse hydrological conditions 
after commissioning. These are sufficiently factored into the financial analysis and contingencies 
are provided in the cost estimates; the Project is financially robust enough to withstand these 
risks. In addition to the project-specific risks, the overall financial viability of the sector would have 
an impact on the overall success of the Project. With the increasing commercial financing of new 
investments, the financing cost of the sector will increase with the financial risk profile of the 
sector, and adequate tariff increases and control over operating costs will be required to maintain 
the financial risks of the sector at a level acceptable to financers. A further tariff increase of 5% is 
expected  in  the  second  half  of  2008  in  addition  to  the  6.6%    tariff  increase  approved  in 
January 2007. With the establishment of a competitive power market in 2009, generation tariffs 
will be set by the market and the transmission and distribution tariffs by the regulator. The sector 
is also exposed to foreign exchange and interest rate risks because of the currency mismatches 
between revenues and liabilities.

3.  Policy and Institutional Risks 
63.  Viet Nam is embarking on an ambitious sector reform program aimed at establishing a 
competitive generation market by 2010. This involves converting EVN into a holding company, 
and  divesting  operating  units  of  EVN  engaged  in  power  generation  and  distribution.  The 
regulation of the sector, including soliciting and procuring new generation capacity, will be the 
responsibility of ERAV. One of the major challenges and risks in Viet Nam is implementing this 
reform program while expanding the capacity of the power system to meet the projected 15% 
demand growth per year. Providing adequate comfort levels to potential investors in the sector in 
the context of the incipient power market and evolving regulatory regime—without compromising 
the flexibility required to operate a competitive market—is a major challenge. ADB TA on power 
market design (footnote 7) is providing assistance to ERAV to implement the proposed sector 
reforms.  
 
4.  Social Risks 
64.  In Zuoih commune, about 70% of the population lives below the poverty line. The social 
risks of the Project relate to failure to implement the social safeguard activities prepared in 
accordance  with  ADB  safeguard  policies.  Relocation  and  land  acquisition  can  lead  to 
impoverishment, and loss of traditional social and cultural identity. Certain requirements of ADB 
social safeguard policies aimed at ensuring the restoration and improvement of the livelihoods of 
affected people and compensation for upstream and downstream impacts exceed the current 
practice in Viet Nam. The institutional capacity to implement these measures remains a major risk 
factor. The ability of ethnic minority communities to adapt to new livelihoods at the proposed 
resettlement sites, and competition for natural resources and land with outsiders who may settle 
in the project area because of increased access provided by the Project, have also been identified 
as risk factors. The Project will provide assistance to EVN and the district people’s committee in 
implementing  social  safeguards  and  will  provide  direct  assistance  to  affected  persons  for 
improving their livelihoods.  
 
5.  Environmental Risks 
65.  The main environment risks relate to the effectiveness of implementation of the EMP. 
Ensuring adequate environment standards to minimize adverse impacts on, for example, water 
quality and soil erosion during the construction phase is the responsibility of the contractors. The 
Project will provide adequate support to supervise the contractors in their compliance with these 
requirements. Implementation of the EMP during the operational phase, especially provision of 
adequate financing for implementing the conservation offset, remains a risk. Indirect impacts on 
Song Thanh Nature Reserve caused by increased access and general development of a hitherto 
underdeveloped area with high biodiversity value is also a risk that needs to be managed through 
capacity building and improvement of enforcement capacities of provincial agencies.

B.  Dam Design and Construction 
 
2.  Given the strong rock foundation at the dam site, EVN chose a concrete gravity dam 
constructed with roller compacted concrete (RCC). The dam was designed to Vietnamese 
standards, and the project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) consultant confirmed that 
the design is conservative since the various calculated safety factors are within the allowable 
ranges. The maximum height is 109.5 m and the crest length is 367 m. The dam is located on 
an outcrop of sandstone with inter-bedded siltstone in the Bung river, and has a grout curtain 
and drainage gallery to control seepage and seepage pressure. The dam will be monitored 
during  and  after  construction  for  seepage,  foundation  pore  pressure,  dam  tilt,  opening  of 
induced cracks, concrete temperature, and earthquake acceleration. 
 
3.  A gated spillway designed according to Vietnamese standards (1,000-year design flood) 
will be built into the dam, with five 15 m x 16 m radial gates, a ski-jump chute and a plunge pool.

The spillway is capable of passing the 5,000-year flood1 without causing damage to the spillway. 
The stability of the dam was also checked under a probable maximum flood event2.  
 
4.  During construction, the river will be diverted into a 7 m by 9 m twin box culvert that will 
be part of the dam body. Upstream and downstream rock-fill cofferdams will divert the water into 
and out of the box culverts. The diversion has been designed for a 10-year flood, and it is 
expected that, during the rainy season, the dam under construction could be overtopped. This is 
not expected to cause any damage to the dam structure and this methodology has been 
adopted in construction of other RCC dams around the world. Extreme floods normally last for 
less than 1 week in the wet season from September to December. 
 
C.  Intake Structure  
5.  The intake will be founded on rock, with adequate strength on the right bank of the 
reservoir about 100 m upstream of the dam. The intake structure will be 50 m high and cast in 
concrete.  It  will  be  provided  with  two  trash  rack  bays  and  one  intake  gate  designed  for 
172.7 cubic meters per second (m3/s). 
 
D.  Power Tunnels 
6.  The power tunnels consist of the following: (i) a concrete-lined head race tunnel, 6.8 m in 
diameter and 3,046 m long; (ii) a concrete-lined variable diameter surge shaft about 75 m high, 
of which 21.5 m is above ground; (iii) a 270 m long concrete-embedded steel penstock with a 
diameter of 5.2 m; and (iv) a bifurcation with a diameter of 3.4 m at the end of the steel lining, 
branching to each generating unit at the power station. The rock cover along the head race 
tunnel will range from 60 m to 430 m. Access to the underground works during construction will 
be through three adits. The tunnels are designed to be built by drill and blast excavation, with 
primary  support  of  rock  bolts,  shotcrete,3 and mesh;  and  permanent  support  of reinforced 
concrete.  This  is  the  conventional  approach  used  in  Viet  Nam  for  similar  projects  and  is 
considered conservative at an international level. The linings are grouted to fill any voids and 
fissures on the rock contact. The surge shaft is provided to regulate pressure transients during 
rapid changes in station load, which may results in increase in the gross head by 19.5 m or 
15%. 
 
7.  The  surface-accessed  “pit”  power  house,  comprising  a  superstructure  and  a 
substructure,  is  provided  to  contain  the  two  vertical-axis  Francis  generating  units.  The 
superstructure provides protective housing for the generators and control equipment, as well as 
structural support for the main crane of the machine hall. The superstructure is extended and 
provides for an erection bay that protects component assemblies during inclement weather. The 
substructure, or foundation of the power house, consists of concrete necessary to form the draft 
tube, support the turbine stay ring and generator, and encase the spiral case of the turbines. A 
separate control building housing workshops, offices, and comfort facilities for the operators is 
planned adjacent to the power house.

system,  power transfer among regions, and system loss of load expectation are calculated. The

reservoir will become oligotrophic (nutrient poor) in a short period.  
 
7.  Flora and Fauna. Potential impacts on flora and fauna include (i) vegetation loss during 
construction activities; (ii) potential increase in illegal logging, fuel wood and non-timber forest 
product collection, and illegal hunting (also in Song Thanh Nature Reserve); and (iii) localized 
disturbance  to  wildlife  (e.g.,  macaque  and  turtle  populations).  Removal  of  vegetation  is 
inevitable at the construction sites but damage can be minimized by careful removal of trees. All 
plant and animal species, and vegetation communities are widely distributed and species loss is 
minimal. Surveys in the project sites did not reveal any special habitats for protected animals. 
However, construction activity will disturb animals that may come close to the project sites from 
nearby forested areas. The project will affect the Song Thanh Nature Reserve by inundating an 
area of 143 hectares (ha). The inundated area has been subject to logging and illegal hunting in 
the past, and is now used for non-timber forest products collection.

of the barrier effect of the dam. The large water level variation in the river between the dam and 
the confluence with Cai river will strongly reduce the biological productivity of the river. In the 
stretch downstream of the confluence with Cai river, the impacts on fish will be smaller.  The 
Project will result in a loss of river habitat along a 30 km stretch upstream of the dam, which will 
be replaced by a reservoir with a large 27.5 m water level fluctuation between full supply level 
and minimum operating level (regulation zone). Most of the aquatic life in the regulation zone 
will die because of periodical dry-up. The regulation zone, especially steep slopes, are likely be 
heavily eroded, resulting in a denuded, inorganic, desert-like zone of sand, gravel, and stones

(ii) loss of terrestrial and aquatic biodiversity, (iii) increased pressure on Song Thanh Nature 
Reserve,  (iv) loss  of  river  continuity  because  of  the  dam,  (v)  a  river  section  with  strongly 
reduced flow, and (vi) daily water level fluctuations downstream of the power plant. Mitigation 
measures have been proposed to minimize and regularly monitor the impacts. By implementing 
the EMP, the adverse environmental impacts of the Project can be minimized to acceptable 
levels.  The  proposed  Project’s  anticipated  environmental  benefits  include  less  emission  of 
greenhouse gases, a general contribution to development of the area, irrigation benefits in the 
dry months of the year, and a positive contribution to minimize the salt intrusion problem in the 
floodplain.

approaches to resettlement and ethnic minority planning are significantly different, especially

I.  POVERTY ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  
In recent years, strong economic growth in Viet Nam has resulted in substantial increase in demand for electricity. The draft 
6th Power Development Master Plan expects gross domestic product (GDP) growth of 7.5% per annum over the period 2006–
2020. Electricity demand is expected to grow by 16% per annum over 2006–2010. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
country strategy supports the Government’s energy sector development strategy to supply electricity at an affordable price, 
and to ensure reliable and quality of supply to meet the rapidly growing demand. In particular, ADB will support efforts to 
develop new and renewable energy sources, especially in remote and mountainous areas. The rapid economic growth over 
the past decades has resulted in a sharp decline in poverty rates, from 58% in 1993 to below  20% in 2007 Poverty reduction 
has been a result of rapid, stable, and inclusive economic growth. The Government’s aim is to maintain economic growth of 
7.5% per annum until 2010, and further reduce poverty incidence to 10–11% by 2010. Because of economic growth, Viet Nam 
is already facing a growing deficit of electricity supply. A reliable and sufficient amount of electricity supply is important for 
economic growth. 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                                                  Targeting Classification:  General intervention 
1.  Key Issues  
The Song Bung 4 Hydropower Project is built on the Bung river, a tributary of Vu Gia river, in Zuoih and Ta Bhing communes, 
Nam Giang district, Quang Nam province in central Viet Nam—to sustain economic growth in the region. The Project will 
produce electricity to cover increasing demand in central Viet Nam. It will significantly affect the economy in the form of 
accelerated economic growth, and creating new jobs and a transport system. Jobs are expected to be created as a result of 
industrialization, developed transportation and road networks, support services, and other multiplier effects. Following ADB’s 
Enhanced Poverty Reduction Strategy (December 2004), projects classified as general intervention no longer require project 
level poverty assessment. The main project impacts are anticipated in Nam Giang district of Quang Nam province and relate 
to land acquisition and reservoir inundation. 
 
II.  SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 
 
The total population of Nam Giang district where the Song Bung 4 Project is located is approximately 20,000. Almost 80% of 
the population consists of ethnic minority groups and 20% is Kinh (Vietnamese). Among the ethnic minority groups, 56% is Co 
Tu, 19% Gie Trieng, and the rest belongs to other ethnic groups. Nam Giang district is one of the districts with high incidence 
of poverty—about 52.6% of the population is below poverty line. The Project will directly affect five communes: Ta Bhing, Ca 
Dy, Thanh My, Cha Val, and Zuoih in Nam Giang district. Reservoir inundation will affect ethnic minority people from the 
following villages: Thon 2, Pa Dhi, Pa Rum A, and Pa Rum B in Zuoih commune; and Pa Toi and Vinh in Ta Bhing commune. 
Land acquisition in project construction sites, including the dam site and transmission line, will affect people from 15 villages 
in three communes: Ta Bhing, Ca Dy, and Thanh My.  
 
Reservoir Inundated Villages. The four ethnic minority (Co Tu) villages—Thon 2, Pa Dhi, Pa Rum A, and Pa Rum B in Zuoih 
commune—will have be relocated for the creation of the reservoir. Some 206 households with a population of 971 will be 
physically relocated, and 52 Co Tu households in Ta Bhing commune will lose more that 10% of upland cropland and grazing 
land. A further 21 Co Tu households will be affected, as they will be one of the host villages for resettlers. A large percentage 
(45.2%) of the population in the four villages is below 18 years and the education level is low. The majority of Co Tu 
household heads have only elementary education or no education. The most common health problems in Zuoih commune are 
respiratory infections, influenza, pneumonia, bronchitis, and diarrhea. Malaria occurs mainly in the rainy season. Poverty is 
widespread in Zuoih commune, which is one of the poorest communes in Nam Giang district. In Zuoih commune, 72.2% of 
the population lives below the poverty line. A socioeconomic survey in four affected villages indicates that 60% of the 
households in Parum B and 40% in Parum A do not have sufficient rice supply to last a year. These households relied on a 
mixed staple of rice and cassava. In Pa Dhi, 50% of households depend on mixed staples. Thon 2 village is better off in 
comparison with the other three villages. These four villages are remote and located far from the district center. They have 
poor infrastructure and social services. The Co Tu villages in Zuoih commune have no access to newspapers but more than 
half of the families have radio. The Co Tu people in Zuoih commune are heavily dependent on subsistence farming, non-
timber forest products, and river fishery.

Analysis of social, economic, and cultural conditions of the four affected villages are described in detail in volume 2 of the 
resettlement and ethnic minority development plan (REMDP). Reservoir inundation and relocation will entail loss of rice fields,

Project Lands. Most of the land for dam construction and the transmission line is in nine villages in Ta Bhing and Ca Dy 
communes and Thanh My town. Most of the people in Ta Bhing and Ca Dy are Co Tu and Thanh My town is 56% Kinh. The 
affected villages due to transmission line are located along highway 14D and Ho Chi Minh Trail and are accessible throughout 
the year. The ethnic minority people from these villages have more contact with Kinh people than those in Zuoih commune. 
The rate of poverty is lower in Ta Bhing, Ca Dy, and Thanh My communes than in Zuoih commune. In Ta Bhing, 50.1% of 
people (mostly Co Tu) are living below the poverty line; the percentage living below the poverty line is 45.4% in Ca Dy and 
31.5% in Thanh My. Both agricultural land and forestlands will be affected in the impact zone due to the land acquisition for 
project construction area. Fishponds and cattle grazing may also be affected. Thirty one Co Tu households are likely to loose 
more than 10% of their productive assets due to land acquisition for project construction lands. The mitigation measures for 
the affected households are included in the resettlement plan for project lands (REMDP, volume 3). 
 
Downstream Villages. The downstream impact includes 11 communes in Dai Loc district and one village in Nam Giang 
district. People living in downstream villages in Dai Loc district are all Kinh except for one village in Nam Giang district where 
all 39 households are Co Tu. The main impact would be loss of fisheries. The REMDP includes measures to address the 
downstream impact (REMDP, volume 4). Several Co Tu villages in the upstream area may be affected by loss of migratory 
fish because of the barrier effect of the dam.  
 
 
1. Provide a summary of the consultation and participation process during the project preparation. 
 
Consultations (REMDP, volume 1) were held with the affected communities, government officials, and commune officials to 
discuss  the  Project,  resettlement  activities,  impact  of  the  Project,  mitigating  measures,  and  livelihood  improvements. 
Consultations were held with the affected communities to discuss reservoir inundation impacts, proposed resettlement sites, 
and their entitlements, downstream and upstream riverine impacts and proposed entitlements, project construction land 
acquisition, and potential health impacts. Further consultation will be held during the implementation phase.

C.   Gender and Development 
1.  Key Issues.  
 
The relocation and land acquisition of the Project pose a risk to women’s social, economic, and health conditions. The women 
are more vulnerable to changes in the physical environment and changes to their productive resources as they lack social 
coping mechanisms.  The Project is likely to disrupt most of social infrastructure in the Zuoih commune due to relocation, 
especially the health and education services. The Project will also result in Co Tu women having more contacts with 
outsiders, including construction workers, and more access to their villages. This may result in loss of cultural identity and 
exploitation of women including trafficking.

technical and commercial evaluations of the construction and supply contracts; (ii) supervise the

(ix) supervise the installation and erection of the equipment at project site, and the testing and 
commissioning programs; (x) review the updated resettlement and ethnic minority development 
plan (REMDP) to ensure compliance with relevant ADB policies and the objectives of the 
REMDP  of  improved  and  sustained  livelihoods  for  affected  persons;  and  (xi)  monitor 
implementation of the REMDP to ensure compliance with ADB policies.
